description: A previous marriage, cancer and eventually a long-distance romance.
title: From Ordeal to Fairy Tale, but Not Without Obstacles
title_page: From Ordeal to Fairy Tale, but Not Without Obstacles - The New York Times
text:
At the fund-raiser, Mr. Schleifer decided to lay it on thick. “I had the feeling I should go the tough-guy-cancer route,” he said. “The weathered-by-life route.” He told her about the car accident, his illness and failed marriage. But all his hardships had left him a better man, he said.
“Cancer and divorce, these things toughen you up in a certain way,” he explained. “You put things in perspective about what real challenges are. Like, if your coffee is cold in a restaurant, you don’t flip out. Other people have it a lot worse.”
It worked. “He seemed like a survivor,” she recalled thinking. “And not in a cancer way at all. Just in general.”
But there was one big thing that he hadn’t mentioned: Arkadi, the son from his first marriage. It came up when they texted back and forth the next day about going on a date, possibly that Wednesday. He replied that on Wednesdays he had “a standing date with a very charming 5-year-old.”
There were many things he could have said about Arkadi. An aspiring genetic scientist, he is a first-grader who listens to “Planet Money” on NPR and is pushing for Obama to have a third term. But Mr. McGuire-Wien had warned Mr. Schleifer, “It’s not easy to break the kid thing to girls, especially career-driven girls with jobs lined up in New York.”
Indeed, Ms. Latner recalled being taken aback. “I think almost no woman would find it attractive — a man with a child,” she said. “I never saw myself as a mother. Children are very needy, and that is challenging for me. When I was 20, I lived in Italy and had to take care of this colicky Italian baby. If everyone had to take care of a baby for one summer before having one, they’d think twice about having children.”
